name: Xinyu Wang 0006
content: Xinyu Wang Xinyu Wang Assistant Professor Computer Science and Engineering University of Michigan, Ann Arbor Email: xwangsd@umich.edu Office: 4620 Beyster Twitter: @xwangsd [Research] [Teaching] [Publications] [Team] [Service] [CV] What's new?! PhD positions available for Fall 2026. Research positions for undergraduates and masters students: take a look at this link. I am a tenure-track assistant professor in the Electrical Engineering and Computer Science Department at the University of Michigan. My research interests are in the areas of programming languages, formal methods, software engineering, and artificial intelligence. Previously I was a researcher at Microsoft. I obtained my Ph.D. from the University of Texas at Austin. Research My work is centered around program synthesis—more generally, AI-assisted programming—with the goal of transforming how software is created. Specifically, my work aims to develop general principles that can reliably scale program synthesis, and build synthesis-aided programming systems to enable easy creation of software across of a wide range of application domains. The particular methodology I've been taking to realize this vision is largely application-driven, by synergistically combining (1) insights from the application domain and (2) techniques from the areas of formal methods, programming languages, AI/ML, and human-centered computing. The hope is that, by better solving very hard technical problems from important domains, we can also develop new insights around program synthesis that can generalize to and benefit other domains. Below are some directions that we have been working on lately... AI-Assisted Programming for Computational Science New direction. Details forthcoming... We are hiring at all levels. Please reach out if you're interested! Formal Methods for Optimizing Analytic Queries Publications: Polygon [PLDI 2025], VeriEQL [OOPSLA 2024, VLDB 2024 demo], SlabCity [VLDB 2023] TL;DR: We've been developing synthesis-aided techniques that can optimize a significantly larger class of queries than existing work—specifically targeting complex analytical workloads. Realizing this vision requires more powerful program reasoning techniques (including synthesis as well as verification, testing, etc.) tailored towards database query languages (like SQL), but we believe the resulting ideas will also advance formal methods and programming languages in general. Neuro-Symbolic Agents for Process Automation Publications: Arborist [POPL 2024], MIWA [UIST 2023], DiLogics [UIST 2023], WebRobot [PLDI 2022], SemanticOn [UIST 2022], WebQA [PLDI 2021] TL;DR: We've been developing new synthesis algorithms and interaction mechanisms to enable easy creation of web automation programs (to automate web-related tasks such as data scraping, data entry, form filling, etc.), by simply describing the task logic in natural language and demonstrating how to perform it in a web browser. The goal is to eventually simplify the creation, deployment, management, and maintenance of such automation programs to enable automation of tasks that involve interactions across multiple applications.
